Reese.
The speaker was born in Baltimore, November 4, 1862. He was.
graduated from the University of
Virginia in 1884. He studied abroad
at Heidelberg under Bunsen, there
receiving the degree of doctor of
philosophy in the spring of 1886.
He then proceeded to Gattingen to
work in organic chemistry under
Victor Meyer.
Holds Numerous Degrees

Both the University of Pennsylvania and Colgate University conferred on him the honorary degree
)f doctor of sciences in 1919; and
in 1920 he was made a member of
Phi Beta Kappa by the University
')f Virginia. For 14 years after his
return from Germany in 1886 Dr.
keese was engaged in teaching. In
1900 he began his industrial life as
thief chemist for the New Jersey
zinc Company. His work there at'racted the attention of the du Pont
..ompany and in 1902 he was ap)ointed chief chemist of the Corn)any. At the beginning of 1920
here were over 400 chemists in
he chemical department of the
ompany. This great organization
was built up under the direction of
)r. Reese, and its success is due to
is foresight in planning the organzation and his executive ability in
:arrying out those plans.
Dr. Reese is a fellow of the
\.merican Association for the Ad7ance of Science, member of the
kmerican Chemical Society, the Soiety of Chemical Industry, the
kmerican Institute of Chemical En;ineers, the Franklin InS'titute,
''-hemists' Club of New York and
Iarious other honorary and scienific organizations. At present he
s president of the American Chemcal Society.

The "Cage Fund" will receive
the proceeds from the long-discussed second lacrosse tilt between
the Mount Washington Country
Club and Johns Hopkins when
these two teams meet tomorrow at
Homewood Field.
The Jays and the Wolfpack had
considered several other dates but
finally came to a decision to play
Saturday at 3.30 P. M.
Funds For Cage

The entire gate receipts will be
turned over to the drive for $5,000
to aid in the construction of a cage.
The center wooden cheering section
stands at Homewood Field will be
reserved for students only at $.55
per seat. The seats in the concrete
stands will be reserved at $1.50
each. A large attendance of students, faculty and alumni are expected to attend. Tickets may be
procured at the treasurer's office
or at the field.
The last time these two teams
met this season the Jays defeated
the Wolfpack 8-6 but only after an
extra period was played. Since that
time the Hopkins ten has defeated
St. John's and Maryland and by
virtue of these victories has retained its national title.
Although the tilt tomorrow will
in no way endager the Jays' clams
to the national crown it will be interesting to see if the Black and
Blue ten can defeat Mount Washington again and maintain its undefeated record.

pleted a rather mediocre campaign

by the Haverford aggregation. Although the Black and Blue captured
only one of their five, meets, every
contest was extremely close with
Maryland being the sole squad able
to defeat Hopkins by any appreciable margin.
While the team as a whole was
not very successful, several individual performers built up enviable
records While sporting the Black
and Blue. Chief among these undoubtedly was Paul Holtzman, Jay
two-mile ace, who completed the
season with an undefeated dualmeet record. Holtzman was the only
Hopkins trackman to defeat the
representatives of all five colleges
on the Jays' schedule. He climaxed
his season last Wednesday when he
came up from behind on the last lap
to pass two Terp runners and win
in the time of 9.58.

Racquetters Finish
Extensive Schedule
With Seven Wins
Seven victories against five defeats tells the record of the Hopkins tennis team this year. The Blue
Jays defeated George Washington
University, Georgetown, Gettysburg, Haverford, Swarthmore,
Loyola and Baltimore University,
while setbacks were handed them
by Navy, Princeton ,Army, Lehigh
and North Carolina.
Two matches with Yale and the
University of Maryland were cancelled on account of rain.
In spite of the definite handicap
of the poor condition of =the courts
at Hopkins this year which practically prohibited all practice sessions,
Capt. Brooke and his netmen, Siverd, Ladensky, Hartman, MacGregor, Blum, Palitz, Kramer and
Buck, turned in a commendable record.
The two most interesting matches
of the season were those with
Georgetown and North Carolina.
The Jays defeated Georgetown 5-4
and lost by the same score to North
Carolina.

Reese.
The speaker was born in Baltimore, November 4, 1862. He was.
graduated from the University of
Virginia in 1884. He studied abroad
at Heidelberg under Bunsen, there
receiving the degree of doctor of
philosophy in the spring of 1886.
He then proceeded to Gattingen to
work in organic chemistry under
Victor Meyer.
Holds Numerous Degrees

Both the University of Pennsylvania and Colgate University conferred on him the honorary degree
)f doctor of sciences in 1919; and
in 1920 he was made a member of
Phi Beta Kappa by the University
')f Virginia. For 14 years after his
return from Germany in 1886 Dr.
keese was engaged in teaching. In
1900 he began his industrial life as
thief chemist for the New Jersey
zinc Company. His work there at'racted the attention of the du Pont
..ompany and in 1902 he was ap)ointed chief chemist of the Corn)any. At the beginning of 1920
here were over 400 chemists in
he chemical department of the
ompany. This great organization
was built up under the direction of
)r. Reese, and its success is due to
is foresight in planning the organzation and his executive ability in
:arrying out those plans.
Dr. Reese is a fellow of the

The "Cage Fund" will receive
the proceeds from the long-discussed second lacrosse tilt between
the Mount Washington Country
Club and Johns Hopkins when
these two teams meet tomorrow at
Homewood Field.
The Jays and the Wolfpack had
considered several other dates but
finally came to a decision to play
Saturday at 3.30 P. M.
Funds For Cage

The entire gate receipts will be
turned over to the drive for $5,000
to aid in the construction of a cage.
The center wooden cheering section
stands at Homewood Field will be
reserved for students only at $.55
per seat. The seats in the concrete
stands will be reserved at $1.50
each. A large attendance of students, faculty and alumni are expected to attend. Tickets may be
procured at the treasurer's office
or at the field.
The last time these two teams
met this season the Jays defeated
the Wolfpack 8-6 but only after an
extra period was played. Since that
time the Hopkins ten has defeated
St. John's and Maryland and by
virtue of these victories has retained its national title.
Although the tilt tomorrow will
in no way endager the Jays' clams
to the national crown it will be interesting to see if the Black and
Blue ten can defeat Mount Washington again and maintain its undefeated record.

pleted a rather mediocre campaign
last Wednesday. The Jays dropped
encounters to Maryland, Swarthmore and Delaware, and were tied
by the Haverford aggregation. Although the Black and Blue captured
only one of their five, meets, every
contest was extremely close with
Maryland being the sole squad able
to defeat Hopkins by any appreciable margin.
While the team as a whole was
not very successful, several individual performers built up enviable
records While sporting the Black
and Blue. Chief among these undoubtedly was Paul Holtzman, Jay
two-mile ace, who completed the
season with an undefeated dualmeet record. Holtzman was the only
Hopkins trackman to defeat the
representatives of all five colleges
on the Jays' schedule. He climaxed
his season last Wednesday when he
came up from behind on the last lap
to pass two Terp runners and win
in the time of 9.58.

accomplished a jump that surpassed
the 22-ft. mark.
Other Hopkins men who turned
in consistently good performances
are Chancellor, Moravek, Weeks,
Coburn, Peppler, Clark, Emmert
and Graziano.

Racquetters Finish
Extensive Schedule
With Seven Wins
Seven victories against five defeats tells the record of the Hopkins tennis team this year. The Blue
Jays defeated George Washington
University, Georgetown, Gettysburg, Haverford, Swarthmore,
Loyola and Baltimore University,
while setbacks were handed them
by Navy, Princeton ,Army, Lehigh
and North Carolina.
Two matches with Yale and the
University of Maryland were cancelled on account of rain.
In spite of the definite handicap
of the poor condition of =the courts
at Hopkins this year which practically prohibited all practice sessions,
Capt. Brooke and his netmen, Siverd, Ladensky, Hartman, MacGregor, Blum, Palitz, Kramer and
Buck, turned in a commendable record.
The two most interesting matches
of the season were those with
Georgetown and North Carolina.
The Jays defeated Georgetown 5-4
and lost by the same score to North
Carolina.
